_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Frozen Fruit, Juice, and Vegetable Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A. Describe the Accident Release Prevention and Emergency Policies



Nestle Professional Beverages has long been committed to maintaining a high degree of employee safety and community relations.  To these ends, the facility maintains an active safety management program to prevent releases of ammonia.  The facility's overall approach to safety is the prevention of accidents, and emphasis on safe work practices.  A planned schedule of inspection and maintenance activities, augmented by worker training, is intended to prevent accidents and releases.  A system of automatic detection and alarm devices is employed to give early warning of releases.  The facility manually integrates alarm situations with off-site response providers, such as Siemens Life System, and the Chicago Fire Department.



Senior management remains committed to this program of safety and safe procedures.  The implementation of safe working procedures and chemical safety is directed at the level of Vice President, who is responsible for corporate policy and facility compliance.





B.   Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



Nestle Professional Beverages is a food manufacturer engaged in the blending and packaging of a variety of beverages in food service packages.  Located at the boundary between an industrial area and a residential area, the facility imports by truck a variety of juice concentrates and blends them into finished products.  Packaging materials, wrapping, and shipping materials are also brought to the site.



The need to keep raw materials and finished products refrigerated or frozen requires a large refrigeration capacity.   To supply the demand for this refrigeration capacity, the facility operates an in-plant anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system.  This refrigeration plant was upgraded in 2011.



Ammonia is the only regulated substance handled at the facility.





C.   Description of the Accidental Release Prevention Program



The facility has a program level

3 accident release prevention program for the ammonia system that complies with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard and EPA's Risk Management Program Regulation.  The ammonia prevention program consists of the following elements:



o Employee Participation Program

o Process Safety Information

o Process Hazard Analysis

o Operating Procedures

o Training Program

o Contractor Safety Program

o Pre-Startup Safety Review Procedures

o Mechanical Integrity Program

o Hot Work Permit Procedures

o Management of Change Procedures

o Incident Investigation Procedures

o Compliance Audit Procedures





D.   Five-Year Accident History



There have been no accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage in the past 5 years. 





E.   Description of the Emergency Response Program



An emergency response program has been implemented at the facility.  This program contains procedures describing how the facility will respond to ammonia releases and other emergencies, including evacuation procedures.  



The emergency response program is coordinated with the Chicago Fire Department.





F.   Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Currently there are no planned facility upgrades at this time.
